NOTICE: My review is only for those who want an honest review of the game and are worried if this game is worth it, because of the negative reviews.

Disney Infinity 3.0 for PC is a good game for what it is. It isn't free, that I can assure you, there are however three free demo characters you are provided with that change every other week or so and a few power discs that are provided for you (From Star Wars, Marvel, and Disney themselves) so you don't have to buy any right away. This game seems more intended for those who are familiar with the console's mechanics of the gameplay. Having the console version, I can reassure you this game is fine but is lacking online multiplayer yet and of course there are some packs or characters you may have to buy. But if you compare it to the console, it is nearly no different apart from the fact that on PC you can create much bigger worlds.This game isn't bad, it's just a matter of whether or not you're willing to pay for characters and small discs packs which is really just an option and not a demand. (Which are pricier on console because the figures come with both a card for PC redeem and the figure itself). To put it simply, I recommend this game if you're a fan of disney, have a few dollars on the side to spend if you wish and don't mind playing by yourself (For now while they work on an online multiplayer update). The game is still pretty enormous even if you don't pay for much, if not anything at all, the game doesn't rely on purchases of anything, but it is recommended maybe a pack or a charcater, or two, for your collection, which aren't pricy on their own at all for PC.

If you are looking to have fun in a Disney Sandbox game, with various dlcs and neat characters and cheap packs, none of which are demanded, then this is a game I can recommend.

If you have no intentions of purchasing anything at all or playing a game that requires some patience while the Developers continue to work on it, then this game isn't for you.

Horrific control scheme for keyboard and mouse.  Game controllers are completely unusable on PC out of the box.

Obvious console port is obvious.  The game makes direct reference to the RFID reader which is not usable on PC.

Ah yes, and let's not ignore the gaping security risk that is the Disney Infinity website.  Third-party cookies are set and executed when you attempt to log in.  There is no information for the general public as to what Disney is actually doing when you browse.  Only people with third-party cookies disabled will even know something nefarious is being done.

Encourages you to play community levels, but fails to inform you that you do not have an unlocked character to play said levels.  Forcing you to endure long load times for low-poly, low resolution textured garbage.

Summary:  Disney Infinity 3.0 is just another in the long line of unimaginative and poorly executed games that are signalling the death of games as art for the mass market.

reviewText:
I went on a whim and downloaded this even though it has such a bad review average. And I am surprised, or actually puzzled... I am not quite sure why so many people downrate the game for the store and the player having to buy pretty much everything. Not that I am DEFENDING it, it's just... when I first saw Infinity figures at the store, I read about it, and learnt that the BASIC IDEA is to buy those figures so you could use them in your game (and have the figures on your shelf, I guess). That's what I heard the game was based on.

So I was surprised people complain about just THAT. However, is the F2P-thing a lie? Kinda, but not entirely. You CAN play the game and unlock some stuff for your toybox, you can do the daily challenges and dabble around with a very very basic toybox (the building-area). In order to do so, you can use three characters that are available for trying. The three available ones are switched every week, AFAIK. When I tried it, I was able to play Olaf, Asokah and Hulkbuster.

I then went on Ebay and searched for Infinity webcodes (the code the figures come with. You can type them into the store in game and unlock the respective character). For 1 EUR, I was able to buy Luke Skywalker (be careful! Some of the guys sell codes for a EUR or two, but ask for like 11 EUR shipping cost, which is silly, as they can just email you the code).

Now, what is the game like? It's fun! It ofc is aimed at younger players, and is totally safe to be played by your child... it's kinda cute, and has a mix of jumping, running, climbing, melee and ranged combat (each character has unique abilities, and you can unlock more).
It's not terribly challenging, but IMO, it's made with some love for the franchises (Disney/Marvel/Star Wars). It has references to all those movies and characters, a great soundtrack (of course it does, as they can use the soundtrack from, like, the SW movies), and you will find a lot of very familiar characters.
Of course, it's a matter of taste whether you like the graphics, whether you like to play jump and run in some Alladin-area with a SW-character, etc
IMO, this is a fun casual game. Of course, you have to invest some money to unlock stories and characters, but even if you don't, you can use the trial-characters and check out demos of the stories, the toybox and the daily mission.
And yes, there is a STRONG focus on microtransactions, but what do people expect, it's the basic idea of the Infinity-system.
If you are looking for a nice, casual, simple action/jump/combat-game with tons of Disney-flavor, check it out.

Updates for DI seem sporadic for the PC version and as new features are introduced to consoles while deficiencies on the PC are not addressed I can not recommend investing in the DLC for continued play.  Download the free client and take walk down memory lane with what feels to be an amusing button masher but don't take the experience any further unless the developers make some kind of effort to inprove the experience and address the disparities.

reviewText:
Not one to write reviews but after seeing how much negative reviews this game gets I felt it necessary to write one. I must admit that I was very hesitant to download the game in the first place because reviews on all platforms this game is available on were very negative (Steam, Google Play Store, Windows Store, Amazon). However most reviews tended to be the same complaint about having to pay for things so I decided to try for myself and being a huge star wars fan I really wanted to try this for the star wars alone, I admit I’m not much of a Disney guy...til now.

TL;DR Game is awesome, fun, excellent. Quit your whining about having to buy things as this game is not as bad as other games are with their microtransactions and pay to win schemes. Characters are good. Don’t buy toy box unlock if you have an APU, Don’t buy toy box unlock unless you know for sure your computer can handle building in the toy box. Highly recommend.

In my experience free to play games offer little and want too much for nothing and most are really pay to win schemes. All free to play games are free to enter but charge a ton on microtransactions (buy coins for this buy coins for that) then charge you upwards of $20 or more for packs that allow you to have the better weapons etc. Disney Infinity however is nothing like that, there are no micro transactions as you can win the blue sparks (the play money used to buy toy box content) with everything you smash and every enemy you kill.

Characters are not free but you can use the trial ones for a limited period and then choose other characters each time, you can level them  up and if you ever do buy the character their levels and powers are still there.

As a free player you have the ability to play the daily challenges, visit and play in any of the community toy boxes which are plenty so there is always something to do.

Buying the playsets allows you to play each playset plus you get two or more characters. You don’t have to spend too much on the characters or the playsets, you can buy them on Ebay or trade them on reddit (web code only). You can unlock all the star wars playsets and characters for about $20 if you are patient and shop around for deals. The playsets are really fun and collecting all the characters  in a series by hunting them down on ebay and other places is fun in itself, I mean who doesn’t like finding a playset worth $19.99 for only $2? It’s like finding treasure!

All in all the game is fantastic, fun and just plain awesome. The characters look great, each with its own unique powers and weapons. The playsets have a good story and offer hours of fun. “Infinity” things to do.

Of course nothing is perfect and this game comes with its glitches some of which are very annoying sometimes almost not allowing you to play. Some of these glitches include not being able to use the mouse properly as the sensitivity seems to be broken and therefore making flying or pod racing nearly impossible…..that is if your computer cannot handle the graphics. Way to get around most issues is to lower the screen resolution in the main game menu options down to the lowest and then most issues in this game are gone. Be aware that this game does not support APUs so Disney will not offer support for some of the games problems but to be honest they did try to help me even after the fact that my craptop is very low spec and did not meet their system requirements.


Pros:
-Infinite hours of fun
-Good looking characters
-Good gameplay
-Good stories
-Good graphics
-No microtransactions (unless you want to spend money on sparks which you can get free in game)
-No pay to win

Cons:
-Glitches, many - However most are due to my piece of caca laptop not meant for gaming so basically I do not count it against the game itself.

-No APU support, DO NOT I REPEAT DO NOT buy the toy box unlock unless you KNOW your computer can handle building in the toy box. You can try this out during the tutorial, if you get the “performance” warning and does not allow you to place objects then you most likely cannot build and if your laptop has APU then it will be nearly impossible for you to use the toy box. I say nearly because there are ways around it but still very limited. I would say simply you can’t use the toy box. Disney will not be fixing this either so be advised. I made the mistake of buying the toy box unlock but glad that I was able to get a refund from steam.

-No Multiplayer - it is very sad that this is not available...yet and possible never on PC

I highly recommend this game. Two thumbs and two big toes up.

reviewText:
I'm actually having a fun time in this. Granted, this is mostly because I already have characters and playsets because I own the console version, but I think that's really the point. This is here for those who already bought the stuff but want to play on PC, and it does it well. The only things I really have to rebuy is my hexdiscs, even then it's cheaper than buying the blind bags and hoping you get what you want.


Now I can understand the negitive reviews. Disney Infinity 1.0 for PC gave you a full Toybox adventure and a free character just to get you started. 3.0 doesn't do the same, but instead lets you demo all the Toybox adventures it has to see if you want to buy them. But you're getting the base game itself for free. Consoles can't.

But out of all the negitive reviews, only a few can be seen as legit
-Multiplayer is still not in
-Devs recently abandoned the PC version for an indefinite ammount of time

For what it is, it's a good game. It's the closest we can get to a LittleBigPlanet type game for PC, and it's great at that. Sure you may have to shift through some trash in the toybox to find good player content, but that goes with any game like it from LittleBigPlanet itself to Super Mario Maker.

PROS:
+ Fun Sandbox type game
+ Unlimited user-generated content
+ Huge cast of characters to play as
+ Cheaply get the exact hexagon discs you want instead of trying your luck with blind bags
+ Buying a physical version of a Toybox Adventure and Figure gives you a free digital copy as well as being able to be used on all platforms

CONS:
- No Multiplayer for PC
- Not backwards compatable with previous Toybox Adventures
- Not all characters can be used with all Toybox Adventures, not even as a 100% Completion reward
- Infinity base not supported, you'll have to buy digital hexagon discs and relevel your own characters
- Can't pick up where you left off on from other platforms
- Anything you buy is only for the Steam version of the game
- Devs have stopped updating the game for the time being

Rating 7.5/10

Final Note: Do not play this unless you already have some adventures and characters. Otherwise this game will do you no good.

reviewText: There are more than just a few limits in this game. First of all, there is the limited content. There are about 6 demos in this free version of the game, and each of them end before things get exciting (they are also very short). Secondly, you have limited character control. Everything about the way the game plays seems clunky, awkward and generally just not enjoyable. Sometimes hitting the attack button will cause characters to jump to nearby enemies and decimate them, other times the characters just punch the air while enemies shoot at you from 3 feet away. The camera controls are just horrendous. It takes 5-10 seconds to reposition the camera to where you want it to be due to incredibly slow camera movement and no dynamic camera positioning (something that Super Mario 64 managed 18 years ago). Finally, there is limited room for exploration since levels are incredibly linear, and they are constantly being interrupted by short cutscenes and tutorial tips (despite asking to skip the tutorial).\n\nIf you ignore the fact that the majority of the content is locked behind ridiculously overpriced paywalls this game is decent. It has a nice (albeit dated) visual style, a great cast of characters, and the gameplay isn't awful. It's not good, but not awful. However, unless you want to spend £100+ for a decent game when there are plenty of great family games out there for a quarter or less of the price (e.g. LEGO Star Wars), I cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
The important take-away for the PC version is that it is better in every possible way than the console versions... except for its current lack of co-op of any kind. Lack of that feature is killer, but hopefully the developers provide an update to fix that.

So everything except co-op... Running on even a budget gaming PC, the game feels so much better than it does on any console. Smooth 60fps @1080p with maximum settings was easily achieved by my GTX 750 Ti and it greatly improves the feel of the game for having done so. While not a major surprise, compared to the Wii U it is absolutely night and day, and it's similarly ahead of the newer platforms.

Since this is singleplayer-only right now, the feel of the mouse/keyboard setup can take center stage a little better, and that feel is excellent. Star Wars in particular benefits tremendously from the precision of the mouse/keyboard setup, and Ninja Theory's combat system feels more coherent with it as well because mouse-targeting allows more natural combo chaining. My only complaint with these controls is the lack of a quickly-accessible in-game key map guide as while everything works well with the default mappings, they are not always obvious.

The other important aspect of the PC version is how well it works with the purchaseable characters. Which is just fine, perhaps even better than the consoles in many ways. It tends to be much more convenient to load the characters onto your Disney account with a code and to select them from in-game menus than it does to fetch the physical characters and shift them around on the power matt. And of couse you have the flexibility to buy the toy characters to have them for display purposes if you want or to save some money and buy the digital unlocks instead.

I should start by stating the obvious, because most people here don't get it...

This game is not free, at all. And coming from a Disney game you should already know that. The free content is just a demo, and there are also timed free characters. But if you want to play a free game go play Dota or TF2...
This game is FOR KIDS. It has a lot of grinding of simple tasks like collecting items, or destroying objects. Gameplay similar to a LEGO game.
The content is overpriced on Steam. But I just went on ebay and got 3 play sets and 6 more characters for about $20. So only the steam DLC is overpriced, but you can get the same content from other sources for a much lower price.
ProsDecent gameplay. It's a slightly more complex than a hack-n-slash but still simple enough so that kids can play it on their own.
Good variety of characters with skill trees.
Good voice acting and cutscenes, kids love it.
ConsLots of padded content, it looks like you are playing an MMO.
There are only 3 play sets on the PC, and 2 of them are Star Wars related. They should add more play sets.
If you are an adult there is nothing here for you.

Some recent reviews say it's only a demo, but it's not. The Infinity system starts a demo introducing you to the Toy Box, and there are demos of characters to play, but you unlock characters by purchasing an Infinity Model at someplace like Wal Mart, or buy a DLC. Technically, it's not free to play since you have to buy the characters or play sets, but the Disney Infinity 3.0 SYSTEM is free to download - ergo free to play.

We didn't discover that you actually don't need a game console to use Disney Infinity until we bought a PS4, so you don't need a gaming console, just a model and steam account (or probably some other gaming portal that's participating). We also discovered that you can't share characters on Steam like you can on the game console, so that's one drawback. Otherwise, the system is fun, if not really easy to understand about what's a time limit demo character vs. one you buy the figurine for.

We suggest that you download Infinity from Steam and buy a playset from a retailer instead of buying a digital download because the models are universal on all consoles, plus you get the one time redeemable code for online (that you can use in Steam or elsewhere presumably).

One last thing, it's doubtful this is a true single player platform because Infinity has multi-player options, although we've not explored the process for joining lan or online multi-player.

I'm going to explain here few things about the Disney Infinity 3.0.

DLCs DLCs can be:

- Playsets
- Characters
- Power Discs
- Toy Box Games
- Sparks Packs

Playsets are a full story mode game featuring Star Wars Playsets and Inside Out Playset. There are two kinds of each Playset DLC, one includes the Playset & two characters ONLY, and the second includes the Playset, two characters, one of the Toy Box Games and Sparks pack. That is why there are DLCs that cost much, because they contain many thing, a starter pack includes much more than a normal Playset DLC.

Characters are a basic DLC in this game, but you are NOT supposed to buy them all! You can buy only the ones you want, you don't need to think that because there are a lot of characters DLCs then to get the game as a full game you'll need to buy them all, no! Every player is allowed to purchase any character he wants!

Power Discs can be Customization and Toys I'll say here the same as what I said about the characters, you are NOT supposed to buy them all! In fact, the Power Discs are not as useful as the characters are, Power Discs are more like extras.

Toy Box Games are like a mini-Playset. The first one, Toy Box Speedway DLC unlocks a racing game with tracks & cars and is recommended to Mario Kart or Sonic Racing players. Again, it is not a must.
The second DLC is a mix of a Playset + Toy Box + The Daily Challenge, it's a story about the Disney characters which happens in the Toy Box and it's being played as the Daily Challenge is, only Toy Box Takeover has bosses. And Again, it is not a must.

Sparks Packs gives you an in-game currency, which can be used to buy toys in the Toys Store or you can buy Costumes for characters you've bought, more Team Ups or more Battle Helps. Purchasing the Sparks Packs DLCs is not the only way to get Sparkes, you can earn them while you play in any mode, so these DLCs are only if there's something you want in that instant.

Gameplay(Gameplay of the Free to Play version)

Gameplay is amazing, you can beat, shoot, race, build, fly, ride and basiclly anything on this Free to Play version, you even get to play in each Playsets' first level! And you get a weekly ever-changing three characters + 2 characters bonus.
Another thing which is free is the Daily Challenge mode. On that mode you're able to play with any character you want fighting against enemies and a boss on every day! Only this itself could be a free to play game.


All in all this game is 10/10 in my opinion, and people should be greatful for Disney Interactive Studios to make a free to play version on Steam, while there was no Steam free to play version for the 2.0 one.

There seems to be a lot of negative reviews over the way this game works.  Primarily, this game was designed for console use since you have the base portal where you can place your physical figures onto.  The PC version?  Doesn't use either of those so in order to get playsets or characters you need to purchase them digitally via their in-game store or over Steam itself.  That's where people go nuts over it.  What people don't realize though is that you can acquire what you need to play the game elsewhere.

Want the Twilight of the Republic playset but don't want to spend $40?  That's okay.  Find a code on ebay and spend $2 (Rise Against the Empire and Inside Out are also about $4 each).  Yes, it sounds a little scummy but if you're somebody that is very disappointed with the pricing of the game's DLC, then ebay is the best way to go.  For under $50, you can buy quite a lot of playsets and characters which is almost like buying a new game.  The people who buy the physical items for the console versions are more than likely the ones selling those codes for the PC version, so Disney Infinity 3.0 (and other versions) is already being supported.

That being said, I've spent very little money on this game so far and have been enjoying it quite a lot.  Combat for the 3.0 characters (I've only tried out Star Wars ones) is VERY different from previous entries.  Our Jedi friends play more like they belong in an action game, making combat feel more complicated than 2.0's (I haven't tried 1.0) simple button mashing.  From what I can tell, playing as Anakin in Twilight of the Republic, combat felt very similar to combat in Star Wars: The Force Unleashed mixed with a little bit of Kingdom Hearts and for me, that is very fun.   If that's the gameplay you enjoy, then this is right up your alley.

Do yourself a favor and do a bit of research about this game, find other places where you can get the DLC (ebay being the recommendation), and give this game a try when you unlock more of the main content.  You'll find that you might enjoy the game more that way if you get over the biggest hurdle keeping you away from it.  If you're a collector and just want the figures, I recommend buying the physical ones and using the digital codes for the PC version.

Pretty much all of the reviews of this are whining about all the DLC. This is basically Disney's version of Skylanders. We all knew what it was. If you don't want that, then don't buy or play this game.

First, the game needs at least one patch to fix the stupid intro forcing you to watch every time you play. It doesn't seem like game saving is working right. That could be a deal breaker for some people.

Second, the game is built around the toy model still, but it does have some packs of characters and play sets you can buy if you're into that. Also, the sets, packs, characters, etc. all cost less than half of the physical items so if you want a character but don't care about the figure you can save some money buying it from Steam. reviewText:
For people who are unfamiliar with Disney Infinity and the Toys-to-life games:

This game was developed primarily for consoles, as a game for people to buy 'Toy' characters, based on various properties owned by Disney, either for their children or to collect, and play with in their corresponding and most recent games (Each version can go forward into the next, none can play in versions earlier than their release).

Each figure and/or playset comes with its very own web code card, which is redeemable for use in the PC/mobile app versions of this game. As an alternative for those that are completely uninterested in purchasing the physical 'Toys', the PC/mobile game offers you the ability to purchase any toy or playset you desire, at a discounted rate from the physical ones.

The general gist of the Toys-to-Life genre is to put the figures you own, on a base connected to the consumers console platform of choice (Wii U/ PS3/ PS4/ X360/ Xbox One), and see their characters come to life on their television screen. That is lost in the PC/Mobile version of this game.

That being said, it definitely isn't a game for everyone. It has decent platforming and combat, and a decent set of creator tools to create your own areas to play around in. If you aren't into building your own levels, or don't feel like springing for a playset or two, you'll find yourself very limited in what you can do. But if you try the included demos for the playsets, and find that you enjoy it, you'll find a fun game.

reviewText:
Yes, this game gets plenty of bad reviews because it advertises free to play when it's actually closer to a demo in its default state. Does this mean you shouldn't get the game? Absolutely not! The game is very fun and cute, and an absolute blast for Disney/Marvel/Star Wars fans (I fit in all three, so you'll understand my enthusiasm). It is clearly designed by people who very much love the source materials.

So yes, you will have to pay for the playsets if you want to play this game, otherwise you won't have much to do at all. Yes, those playsets are a bit overpriced considering they are completely digital, especially if you are buying individual characters. But bear in mind, buying one playset gives you access to a whole new story, which will grant you a fair length of fun (especially if you explore and do the sidequests).
And then of course, there is the toy box, in which you are free to put things together and let out your creativity as much as you want. I have spent hours customizing my home and I loved every bit of it.
Oh and don't forget that you can also buy the physical sets and use the codes on it--that way you get to keep the cool figures, and play with the characters in the game.

In other words, despite its flaws (I didn't mention it, but the port just cut out multiplayer functions, and there are some bugs here and there), I really enjoy this game, and I definitely recommend you try it as well--maybe give it a go on a console first, if you can.

reviewText:
Bought the game for my Xbox 360 when I saw I could play it on PC. Wait what?

Yes, this is still Disney Infinity - Toys to Life is the whole point! Anyone complaining about the concept clearly didn't do research about what they were buying. The PC game is essentially a tie-in to the console version. You don't NEED a console game, but that's how it's intended. I bought the Xbox 360 base game for 35 bucks (which is the average cost of a playset) and a couple of other figures so I could play them both on PC and my console.

All Infinity characters and playsets you buy physically come with a code you can redeem on the Disney website, which then adds those characters and playsets permanently to your account so you can play them on PC for no extra fees. Whether you think the figures are worth the 10 bucks they charge is up to you. Personally I love them and get excited whenever I get to buy one! The quality is very high, they have a unique and lovable style, and they look great on a shelf. If you're going to collect Disney figures, you might as well use them for playing, and really, collecting is part of the fun with this game! (unless you don't like collecting things, in which case this is probably not the game for you)

I've played the demo of the Inside Out playset, which I loved, and bought the Rise Against the Empire set with Luke and Leia. This turned out to be the Star Wars game I had been waiting for for years! A little reminiscent of the Lego games with a cute style and gameplay that is simply fun. If you like collecting sparks, jumping around, relatively simple combat, and driving fast vehicles, this is the game for you!

Know what you're getting and enjoy it. My recommendation is to get the physical version of the game, but it's not necessary. Hope this helped someone!
